AN OPEN LETTER ON THE FRATERNITY QUESTION.
. of the NEWS-LETTER:
To the Editor
DEAR SIR:—I am glad to see the movement for an understanding between the fraternities in regard to 'pledging." It should rid them of the greatest hindrance to their healthy
growth here—the too early pledging.

4

THE NEWS-LrIVER.

That this evil is as universal as it is detrimental, is evidenced by a letter recently published in The Nezt;s,in which a prep-school teacher complains of the harm done his pupils' work
by the incessant fraternity campaigning.
This is only one side of the medallion. Constant campaigning keeps the brother so
busy developing his chapter, that there is no time left for him to be developed by his fraternity. He literally exists for the fraternity. This is the reverse of what was meant to be.
The fraternity should exist for him. It is not like relations or like large families. It
is not sent from heaven. It was created by the "student" to fill a student's needs. The
moment it ceases to do this, that moment it has ceased to be a functional part of the student's
life,—and it has lost its right to exist.
But, so far, the situation is in the hands of the fraternity men. Any future condition
that does away with fraternities here will arise from their present inability to regulate their
relations.
For that regulation is possible, I have not the least doubt. Of course, the men .delegated to shape it must have an average amount of self-colltrol and imagination, and every
one of them must be capable of the conviction that any attempt to make an arrangement
specially favorable to his crowd—which, from its very nature, could be only a temporary one
—would jeopardize a permanent improvement in the condition of all alike. Given men up to
these requirements, any plan, as first adopted, would probably be all wrong. Like railroad
legislation, it must have time to grow. It may never he quite perfected—no laws anywhere
are ever up-to-date—but give it a chance, and it will not only improve the conditions of chapter life, it will also insure the continuance of fraternities in good odor and forestall a feeling
against them on the part of parents and teachers which has already begun to manifest itself.
In approaching such an attempt, three things at once occur to me as of paramount
importance; first, provide sufficient time for the school boy to realize conditions here; Second,
prevent the tender of an election until a day set by all; third, prevent the acceptance of an
election until some day following.
First, of course, a committee of delegates from each fraternity, ultimately to become a
permanent court. Let it set a date, say toward the end of the Freshman year—upon which
all the fraternities individually offer election to the men they have selected; let it set a date
closely following this upon which every freshman who has received a notice of election meets
the delegates in a body and declares openly his acceptance of election into this or that fraternity,—at the same time, taking oath that he has neither been offered an election, nor has he
accepted one until the dates agreed upon by all. Whereupon, the delegate representing the
fraternity whose invitation he has accepted, then steps forward on the part of the fraternity
and takes an oath to the same effect. And let no candidate be initiated until he has announced his acceptance of election through the delegates assembled in a body.
Such an oath would prevent any fraternity from secretly violating the treaty. Of
course, open violation would mean a rupture of relations. Whether or not, a fraternity would
want to go back upon its agreement, is a matter of reasonable doubt. Whether or not it
could afford to do so, is a matter of reasonable certainty. This agreement, or a similar one
would carry with it benefits which would be both immediate and far-reaching. It would first
of all do away with the indignified scramble known as "robbing the cradle" and the consequent indignation of parents and teachers such as we have recently had evidence of.
It would prevent the bad feeling resulting from "tampering with pledged men,"—
which never finds expression, and is more intense than if it did.
It would put the fraternities in a dignified position toward the incoming men, and
enable them to exercise a disciplinary effect corresponding to that at Princeton, and at other
places where the honor is held before the freshman, at the formative time of his college life.
It would give everybody time to realize what he was about, which would in turn pre"mistakes."
As a result, the student-body would settle into place easily and naturally

most of their point since the final decision of the Inter-Fraternity Conference that no definite
agreement in the matter of pledges should be entered upon. Notwithstanding the fact that

pledging clause, nothing was done regarding the remaining articles of the agreement and the

JOINT CONCERT.
The Joint Concert by the Woman's College
and Hopkins proved to be a great success.
Everyone who attended was very much
pleased with the entire performance. Many
pronounced it the best concert that they had
heard for several years. Every number on
the program was enjoyable and well rendered.
The features which were most popular with
the audience were the solos, all of which were
exceptionally go od ; the medley by the
Woman's College Glee Club; and the "Song
of the Vikings," which was sung by the two
Glee Clubs—a chorus of about fifty voices.
This was, indeed, a splendid number. It was
a beautiful sight to see the girls in their caps
and gowns, each wearing a bouquet of flowers,
and the men in evening dress with a spray of
lillies of the valley in their lapels.
The decorations of the hall added to the
festivity of the occasion. The stage was
banked with palms, above which were hung
in the center the Woman's College flag and
the Hopkins flag. Around the sides of the
hall were tastefully draped the class banners
of the two colleges. Very pretty programs
were made for the concert. They contained
the picture of each club, a list of the
members of the clubs, and also the
patronesses.
Everything went off without a hitch and
consequently the concert did not drag in a

single place. Although they began at halfpast eight, and although there were no waits
between numbers, the concert was not over
until eleven o'clock. A proof that the concert was not boring was that everyone sat
through to the end.
Aside from the concert being such a success
in a musical and social way, it was just as
much so from the financial side. While the
manager is unwilling to state the exact
amount of profit that each club made, he says
he is perfectly satisfied with the results, and
that now the clubs will be able to take an
Easter trip for three days down the Eastern
Shore. Heretofore the clubs have been
greatly hampered by lack of funds and for
this reason they have not been able to take
any extended trips, as it is impossible to do
so without having any capital. After taking
the Easter trip, the management hopes to have
more than enough to pay off the debt incurred
three years ago. During that year the clubs
were very fine and they took several long trips,
and the season was considered to be very successful and prosperotth, but it is not generally
know that the manager left the clubs with a
debt of over two hundred dollars. This debt
has, however, been reduced by Manager T.
Poole Maynard to about one-half. The management hopes to be able to wipe out this
debt, and to let the clubs start next year unencumbered by any debts.

AN OPEN LETTER ON THE FRATERNITY QUESTION.
. of the NEWS-LETTER:
To the Editor
DEAR SIR:—I am glad to see the movement for an understanding between the fraternities in regard to 'pledging." It should rid them of the greatest hindrance to their healthy
growth here—the too early pledging.

4

THE NEWS-LrIVER.

That this evil is as universal as it is detrimental, is evidenced by a letter recently published in The Nezt;s,in which a prep-school teacher complains of the harm done his pupils' work
by the incessant fraternity campaigning.
This is only one side of the medallion. Constant campaigning keeps the brother so
busy developing his chapter, that there is no time left for him to be developed by his fraternity. He literally exists for the fraternity. This is the reverse of what was meant to be.
The fraternity should exist for him. It is not like relations or like large families. It
is not sent from heaven. It was created by the "student" to fill a student's needs. The
moment it ceases to do this, that moment it has ceased to be a functional part of the student's
life,—and it has lost its right to exist.
But, so far, the situation is in the hands of the fraternity men. Any future condition
that does away with fraternities here will arise from their present inability to regulate their
relations.
For that regulation is possible, I have not the least doubt. Of course, the men .delegated to shape it must have an average amount of self-colltrol and imagination, and every
one of them must be capable of the conviction that any attempt to make an arrangement
specially favorable to his crowd—which, from its very nature, could be only a temporary one
—would jeopardize a permanent improvement in the condition of all alike. Given men up to
these requirements, any plan, as first adopted, would probably be all wrong. Like railroad
legislation, it must have time to grow. It may never he quite perfected—no laws anywhere
are ever up-to-date—but give it a chance, and it will not only improve the conditions of chapter life, it will also insure the continuance of fraternities in good odor and forestall a feeling
against them on the part of parents and teachers which has already begun to manifest itself.
In approaching such an attempt, three things at once occur to me as of paramount
importance; first, provide sufficient time for the school boy to realize conditions here; Second,
prevent the tender of an election until a day set by all; third, prevent the acceptance of an
election until some day following.
First, of course, a committee of delegates from each fraternity, ultimately to become a
permanent court. Let it set a date, say toward the end of the Freshman year—upon which
all the fraternities individually offer election to the men they have selected; let it set a date
closely following this upon which every freshman who has received a notice of election meets
the delegates in a body and declares openly his acceptance of election into this or that fraternity,—at the same time, taking oath that he has neither been offered an election, nor has he
accepted one until the dates agreed upon by all. Whereupon, the delegate representing the
fraternity whose invitation he has accepted, then steps forward on the part of the fraternity
and takes an oath to the same effect. And let no candidate be initiated until he has announced his acceptance of election through the delegates assembled in a body.
Such an oath would prevent any fraternity from secretly violating the treaty. Of
course, open violation would mean a rupture of relations. Whether or not, a fraternity would
want to go back upon its agreement, is a matter of reasonable doubt. Whether or not it
could afford to do so, is a matter of reasonable certainty. This agreement, or a similar one
would carry with it benefits which would be both immediate and far-reaching. It would first
of all do away with the indignified scramble known as "robbing the cradle" and the consequent indignation of parents and teachers such as we have recently had evidence of.
It would prevent the bad feeling resulting from "tampering with pledged men,"—
which never finds expression, and is more intense than if it did.
It would put the fraternities in a dignified position toward the incoming men, and
enable them to exercise a disciplinary effect corresponding to that at Princeton, and at other
places where the honor is held before the freshman, at the formative time of his college life.
It would give everybody time to realize what he was about, which would in turn pre"mistakes."
As a result, the student-body would settle into place easily and naturally

JOINT CONCERT.
The Joint Concert by the Woman's College
and Hopkins proved to be a great success.
Everyone who attended was very much
pleased with the entire performance. Many
pronounced it the best concert that they had
heard for several years. Every number on
the program was enjoyable and well rendered.
The features which were most popular with
the audience were the solos, all of which were
exceptionally go od ; the medley by the
Woman's College Glee Club; and the "Song
of the Vikings," which was sung by the two
Glee Clubs—a chorus of about fifty voices.
This was, indeed, a splendid number. It was
a beautiful sight to see the girls in their caps
and gowns, each wearing a bouquet of flowers,
and the men in evening dress with a spray of
lillies of the valley in their lapels.
The decorations of the hall added to the
festivity of the occasion. The stage was
banked with palms, above which were hung
in the center the Woman's College flag and
the Hopkins flag. Around the sides of the
hall were tastefully draped the class banners
of the two colleges. Very pretty programs
were made for the concert. They contained
the picture of each club, a list of the
members of the clubs, and also the
patronesses.
Everything went off without a hitch and
consequently the concert did not drag in a

single place. Although they began at halfpast eight, and although there were no waits
between numbers, the concert was not over
until eleven o'clock. A proof that the concert was not boring was that everyone sat
through to the end.
Aside from the concert being such a success
in a musical and social way, it was just as
much so from the financial side. While the
manager is unwilling to state the exact
amount of profit that each club made, he says
he is perfectly satisfied with the results, and
that now the clubs will be able to take an
Easter trip for three days down the Eastern
Shore. Heretofore the clubs have been
greatly hampered by lack of funds and for
this reason they have not been able to take
any extended trips, as it is impossible to do
so without having any capital. After taking
the Easter trip, the management hopes to have
more than enough to pay off the debt incurred
three years ago. During that year the clubs
were very fine and they took several long trips,
and the season was considered to be very successful and prosperotth, but it is not generally
know that the manager left the clubs with a
debt of over two hundred dollars. This debt
has, however, been reduced by Manager T.
Poole Maynard to about one-half. The management hopes to be able to wipe out this
debt, and to let the clubs start next year unencumbered by any debts.

Come on, fellows, lets get together for the

Columbia has not been down here for years,
